div.span: An English essayist, poet, playwright, and politician. He founded 'The Spectator' magazine with Richard Steele.
A printer in New York, and involved with the New York Press, possibly as editor. He published Newton's 'Principia' and Maunder's 'Treasury of History.'
An English historical novelist. He wrote the novel 'Rookwood,' along with 39 others, and he created 'Ainsworth's Magazine' with illustrator George Cruikshank.
Founder of the 'New York Literary Gazette' and editor on the 'New World.' He published many of his own poems in the the 'Gazette.'
Author of the 'Divine Comedy.' Dante is considered one of the greatest poets of world literature.
A Scottish advocate and historian, author of 'History of Europe.'
Editor of a two-volume history of the Lewis and Clark expedition written by Nicholas Biddle.

An English philologist. Aram was convicted and executed for the murderer of Daniel Clark. He is celebrated by Thomas Hood in his ballad 'The Dream of Eugene Aram,' and by Edward Bulwer-Lytton in his novel 'Eugene Aram.'
An ancient Athenian statesman and general in the Persian War.
A writer, publisher, composer, singer, visual artist, an illustrator, patron of young talent, and a social activist. She was friends with Goethe and Beethoven.
An English educator and historian. He was headmaster of Rugby School and author of five widely-read books of sermons.
An English philosopher and Franciscan friar who emphasized the study of nature through empirical methods. Author of 'Opus Maius,' which addresses mathematics, optics, alchemy, and astronomy.
An American politician and U.S. Representative from New York.
An Acting Postmaster in New York City under President Andrew Jackson and an advocate for cheaper postal rates.
This is probably a pen name.
A Scottish poet, moralist, and philosopher. Author of 'An Essay on the Nature and Immutability of Truth' and the poem 'The Mistrel.'
A Scottish surgeon, anatomist, neurologist, and philosophical theologian. Bell discovered the difference between sensory nerves and motor nerves in the spinal cord.

An American poet, journalist, editor, and founder of several newspapers. He partnered with Rufus Wilmot Griswold to produce 'The Evening Tattler,' and he helped to found 'The New World.' He was friends with Poe.
A U.S. Senator from Georgia and Andrew Jackson's Attorney General.
A French classical composer and pianist.
Publisher of the 'Broadway Journal.' After the failure of the 'Broadway Journal,' Bisco became a real estate agent.
Creator of the 'Broadway Journal.' Briggs was also an author who wrote under the penname "Harry Franco."
Author of 'Abstract of Elocution and Music.'

An American novelist, historian, and editor. Author of 'Wieland' and other novels. Edited 'The Literary Magazine and American Register' and 'The American Register and General Repository of History, Politics, and Science.'
A theologian. Author of biblical commentaries, 'A Theological Dictionary,' 'A Grammar of the Hebrew Language,' among other publications.
A romantic poet, journalist, and editor of the 'New York Evening Post.' Author of the poem "Thanatopsis."
Also known as Frances Burney and, after her marriage, Madame d'Arblay. An English satirical novelist and playwright. Author of novels 'Evelina,' 'Cecilia,' 'Camilia,' and 'The Wanderer.'
An English journalist and author of "Revelations of the Beautiful and Other Poems," published in 1848. Burrington reviewed many books of poetry for the 'London Press.'
A Scottish writer of sentimental poems, such as "The Pleasures of Hope." Editor of the English magazine, 'The New Monthly Magazine.'
Author of 'Swaim's Justice--Revised: the North Carolina Magistrate.'

A Scottish philosopher, satirical writer, essayist, historian, and teacher. One of the most highly regarded social commentators of his time. Author of "On Heroes, Hero-Worship, and the Heroic in History." His book 'The French Revolutin: A History,' inspired Dicken's 'A Tale of Two Cities.'

An American editor, historian, and author, Carter was involved in the formation of the Republican Party. He created 'The Pioneer, a Literary and Critical Magazine' with James Russell Lowell. Carter sometimes wrote under the penname "Robert Oliver."

An English artist, architect, and explorer, best known for his drawings of Mayan ruins. Wrote 'Incidents of Travel in Central America, Chiapas and Yucatan' and 'Incidents of Travel in Yucatan' with John Lloyd Stephens.
An American painter, author, and traveler who focused on portraits of Native Americans and the Old West. Catlin was the first white man to depict Plains Indians in their native territory.
An Irish writer and novelist best known for 'Traits and Stories of the Irish Peasantry.'
An Italian painter and author of 'Il libro dell'arte,' a treatise on early Renaissance art.
The foremost American Unitarian preacher and theologian of his time. Channing influenced New England Transcendentalists.

An American abolitionist, women's rights activist, Native American rights activist, novelist, and journalist. Wrote the column "Letters from New York" while editing the 'National Anti-Slavery Standard.'

An American doctor-turned-poet and friend of Edgar Allen Poe. He accused Poe of plagiarizing "The Raven" and "Ulalume" from his own work, but he also defended Poe's reputation from attack by Rufus Wilmot Griswold.
An American lawyer, orator, and Congressman.
Author of 'Trifles in Verse: A Collection of Fugitive Poems."
Seems to have been an editor in Rhode Island.
A Democratic member of the U. S. House of Representatives, and later U.S. senator from North Carolina. Clingman served as a general in the Confederate States Army.
An English pamphleteer, farmer, and journalist. Created the 'Political Register,' a weekly newspaper.
An American librarian, bibliographer, and an innovative educator.

An English poet, literary critic, and philosopher. Coleridge was a founder of the Romantic Movement and a member of the Lake Poets. Author of poems "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner" and "Kubla Khan," as well as his autobiography, 'Biographia Literaria.'
A member of the U.S. House of Representatives and, later, U.S. Senator from Vermont. Collamer served as the Postmaster General in the cabinet of President Zachary Taylor.
American educator, editor, and lecturer. He founded the 'American Review,' where Poe's poem "The Raven" was first published.
An American lawyer and minor poet. Edgar Allen Poe encouraged him to submit contributions.
An essayist and author of fanciful, decorous poems. Cowley served as the Queen's ciphor secretary and performed various Royalist missions.
An English poet and hymnodist. A forerunner of Romantic poetry, Cowper influenced the nature poetry of his time by focusing on everyday life.

A Scottish poet and author. Cunningham worked as a parliamentary reporter and journalist in London. He wrote imitations of old Scottish ballands, as well as three novels and a biography of Sir David Wilkie.

American poet, critic, and lawyer. Dana criticized Romanticism and Transcendentalism. Along with other members of the Anthology Club, he founded the 'North American Review.' Dana wrote the gothic novel 'Paul Felton.'
An Italian polymath. Da Vinci painted 'The Last Supper' and 'Mona Lisa.' He also studied science observationally, worked as an engineer, and invented many machines.
United States Ambassador to the Netherlands.

A Cornish chemist and inventor who was first to isolate a series of substances such as potassium, sodium, and calcium. He also invented electrochemistry. He wrote"On Some Agencies of Electricity" and several books.

An American publisher and statistician, DeBow created and edited 'DeBow's Review,' a popular southern magazine that advocated the expansion of southern agriculture and commerce. DeBow urged southern secession from the Union.
An English trader, writer, journalist, pamphleteer, and spy. Defoe is most famous as the author of 'Robinson Crusoe.'

An English writer and social critic, regarded by many as the greatest novelist of the Victorian era. Author of 'Oliver Twist,' 'Bleak House,' 'A Tale of Two Cities,' and 'Great Expectations,' among other works.

Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and an influential creator of the modern Conservative Party. Disraeli is the only British Prime Minister of Jewish birth. He was also a prolific novelist, authoring books such as 'Vivian Grey' and 'Henrietta Temple.'
A medicial doctor in New York, chief physician at the Marine Hospital, and health officer of the port of New York. He edited Good's "Study of Medicine" and translated Magrier's "Midwifery."
An English Nonconformist leader, educator, and hymnwriter. Doddridge is author of 'The Rise and Progress of Religion in the Soul.'

A poet, literary critic, translator, playwright, and England's first Poet Laureate. Dryden wrote the Restoration comedy 'Marriage a la Mode' and the heroic drama 'All for Love.' He also wrote the satires 'Mac Flecknoe' and 'Absalom and Achitophel.'
A courtier and poet. Du Bartas wrote 'L'Uranie,' 'Judit,' 'La Sepmaine,' and 'La Seconde Semaine.'
Author of 'The Count of Monte Cristo,' 'The Three Muskateers,' and 'Twenty Years After.'

A constributor of poems, humorous articles, stories, and sketches to magazines. He translated Alphonse de Lamartine's 'History of the Revolution of 1848,' and he was co-editor of 'Ballou's Pictorial.' Durivage often wrote under the penname "Old Un."

An American publisher and biographer associated with the Young America movement in New York. He assisted Poe in printing his 'Tales' collection, selecting which stories to include. He was editor of 'The Literary World' and he worked with his brother to publish 'The Cyclopaedia of American Literature.'
Editor of 'The New World' weekly paper.
An English painter, gallery director, collector, and writer. He painted 'Christ Lamenting over Jerusalem.'

A progressive thinker and writer of adults' and childrens' literature. Edgeworth was one of the first realist writers in children's literature. She wrote the novels 'Castle of Rackrent' and 'Belinda,' among others.

An American writer, historian, and poet. Ellet wrote 'The Women of the American Revolution,' the first work to record the lives of women who contributed to the American Revolutionary War. Ellet was involved with a scandal in which she accused Frances Sargent Osgood of sending indiscreet letters to Poe.
This is a pen name. The author's real name is unknown.

An author and poet. Embury was an editor for 'Graham's Magazine,' and she wrote a collection of poems titled 'Guido, a Tale: Sketches from History and Other Poems,' as well as the prose work 'Pictures of Early Life.' Embury sometimes wrote under the pen names Rudolph Hertzman and Ianthe
An essayist, lecturer, and poet who led the Transcendentalism movement. He wrote the essays "Nature," "Self-Reliance," and "The Over-Soul."

A Democratic politician who served in the House of Representatives. English was also an author and songwriter: he wrote the ballad "Ben Bolt" for N. P. Willis's 'New York Mirror' and edited the 'American Review.' English became involved in the scandal between Poe, Osgood, and Ellet when Poe asked English to lend him a pistol for defense against Ellet's brother. English did not believe Poe's story and this ended their friendship.

An American diplomatist, politician, and writer. He publications in the 'North American Review' influenced the Trascendentalism movement. He wrote 'Europe; or, a General Survey,' 'New Ideas on Population,' and 'America; or, a General Survey,' among other works.
Author of several works on geology and physical geography such as "Lectures on Geology," published in 1818, and "Geological Essay on the Tertiary Formations in America."
An English chemist who pursued developments in the production of pigments and dyes.
Politican who served as the Governor of New York, a U. S. Senator, and the U. S. Secretary of State under Ulysses S. Grant.
A sculptor and draughtsman, Flaxman was a leading figure in British and European Neoclassism.

A Scottish kirk minister and later a Congregationalist divine in England. He is remembered for preaching to audiences of children and attracting young people to nonconformists chapels through Sunday schools and other events. He is the author of a range of devotional works, including 'A Guide to Family Devotion.'
A French-speaking medieval author and court historian. Froissart wrote 'Chronicles,' which is a history of the Hundred Years' War, as well as the chivalrous romance 'Meliador.'

An American journalist, critic, and women's rights advocate commonly known as Margaret Fuller. Fuller was the full-time female book reviewer, the first editor of the Transcendentalist journal 'The Dial,' and the author of 'Woman in the Nineteenth Century,' considered the first major feminist work in the U.S. Fuller became involved in a scandal between Poe, Frances Osgood, and Elizabeth Ellet when she asked Poe to return Ellet's letters. Poe was angered by this interference, but he praised Fuller's book.
An Irish novelist, playwright, and poet. Goldsmith wrote the novel 'The Vicar of Wakefield,' the poem 'The Deserted Village,' and the plays 'The Good-Natur'd Man,' and 'She Stoops to Conquer.'

An English novelist. Fullerton wrote the novels 'Ellen Middleton,' 'Grantley Manor,' and 'Too Strange Not to Be True,' among other novels and two volumes of verse. In a note on 'Ellen Middleton,' Poe praised the work's "precision of style, the thoroughness, and the luminousness," and he expressed difficulty in believing the book was written by a woman.
An Italian sonnet is attributed to Galeota in the December 12 issue of the 'Broadway Journal.'
A poet and editor for various newspapers. Compiler of one of the earliest American regional poetry anthologies, Selections from the Poetical Literature of the West.

A Swiss-American politician, diplomat, ethnologist, and linguist. Gallatin was the longest-serving U.S. Secretary of the Treasury, and he helped found the University of the City of New York, now New York University.
A Scottish novelist, entrepeneur, and social commentator. He was the first novelist to deal with issues of the Industrial Revolution. He wrote the novel 'Annals of the Parish' among many others.
An English historian, writer, and Member of Parliament. Gibbon wrote 'The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire.'

Full name unknown. "W. G." is credited with the poem "The Sybll" in the October 25 issue of the 'Broadway Journal.' Initials could refer to William Mitchell Gillespie, who was an amateur poet with an interest in classics.

Source: A Vision of Faery Land and Other Poems by William Gibson, Wentworth Press. Information: Attributes "To a Canary Bird" and "The Eternal Father," both printed in the 1846-01-03 edition of the Broadway Journal, to William Gibson, with the above biographical information (birth/death year). High possibility of also being the author of Poems of Many Years and Many Places (Lee and Shepard Publishers-1881).

An American educator, engineer, traveler, authors, and amateur poet. Gillespie wrote books on engineering and math, such as 'A Manual of the Principles and Practice of Road-Making' and 'Subjects and Methods of Instruction in Mathematics,' and well as 'Rome as Seen by a New Yorker,' which Poe praises in his column "The Literati of New York City."

An English journalist, political philosopher, and novelist. Godwin is considered one of the first advocates of utilitarianism and anarchism. He wrote 'An Enquiry Concerning Political Justice,' and 'Things as They Are; or, The Adventures of Caleb Williams,' considered the first mystery novel. Poe praised Godwin's ingenuity in story-telling.
A German writer and statesman. Goethe wrote the novel 'The Sorrows of Young Werther,' and drama 'Faust,' among other works. Goethe also wrote scientific treatises on botany, anatomy, and color.

An American publisher and author. Goodrich's publishing business published the illustrated annual 'The Token,' which featured some of the earlist work of Hawthorn, N. P. Willis, Longfellow, and Lydia Maria Child. Goodrich also established the children's magazine 'Merry's Museum' and wrote children's books. Goodrich is better known under the penname Peter Parley.
An English novelist and dramatist who depicted the gentility and etiquette of high society. She wrote the novel 'Cecil, or Adventures of a Coxcomb,' among others.
Author of 'The History of Etruria' and 'History of Rome for Young Persons.'
Founder and editor of the 'New-York Tribune.' According to a letter written by Poe to Greeley in 1847, Greeley accused Poe of not paying his debts in a 'New-York Tribune' article.

An American gambler, writer, inventot, and eventual reformer. Although he was considered one of the most skilled card players in the U.S., after his retirement he was an anti-gambling activist. He wrote several books, such as 'An Exposure of the Arts and Miseries of Gambling,' and 'Gambling Unmasked.'
Also published as Sarah Josephina Buell Hale.
Often published as Mrs. S. C. Hall.
Hamilton was a Presbyterian minister and theologian who lived and worked in Mobile, Alabama.
Hardin was killed in the Mexican-American War, in the Battle of Buena Vista.
The place where Herodotus died is debated.
Noted as original author of 'The Last of the Plantagenets.'
Some sources list his birth year as 1813.
"Horus" is likely an unknown poet's pen name.
Ide is not, as was once believed, a pen name for Poe.
Also known as George, Count Joannes.
Author of 'The Last of the Plantagenets.'
Mary Clavers is Caroline Kirkland's pen name.
Often published as Anne Lynch Botta.
Full name unknown. Has a set of poems titled "Emblems" published in Graham's Magazine, 1846.
Author of "The Autumnal Leaf"; full name unknown.
English actor. After his death, his name was used to sell joke books.
Wrote "To a Flying Swan," which appears in the 1843 publication Readings in American Poetry. No VIAF information.
Osgood sometimes used the pen name "Clarice," and Pollin identifies Osgood as the author of "Lenore" in the 31 May 1845 issue of the Broadway Journal. Source: www.eapoe.org
This is a pen name. It may be a pen name for Poe.
Some sources list his name as Edward Patterson
Birth name was Johann Paul Friedrich Richter.
A poet, literary editor, periodical writer, linguist, and educator.
This may be a pen name.
Author of "Fancies," "Epicedium," and "A College Reminiscence." Full name unknown.
Marbach am Neckar, Holy Roman Empire
Gulf of La Spezia, Kingdom of Sardinia
Also known as Lydia Howard Huntley.
Also known as Arabelle Jane Wilmot and Mrs. Frederick Sullivan.

Tellkampf is listed as "T.L. Tellkampf" in the 1845-12-20 issue of the Broadway Journal, and again in Poe: Essays and Reviews by Edgar Allan Poe and Gary Richard Thompson, which also mentions his work at Columbia College. A biography for Johann Ludgwig (or Louise) Tellkampf lists his work at Columbia College during the same time period. Thus we infer that the "T" was likely a misprint.
Thomas worked as a newspaper editor in several cities, including Cincinnati, Richmond, and Columbia, South Carolina. He was also a professor of English and rhetoric at the University of Alabama.
Noted for his poem published in the March 'Knickerbocker.'
Noted in Broadway Journal Vol. 1, No. 11 as the author of 'The Use of a Box of Colours'.
Coats is Associate Professor of English and Director of the Digital Scholarship Lab.

Doan is an English PhD student at LSU, who has been involved with developing a digital humanities project about Poe since the fall of 2013. He focuses on 19th century American literature and is particularly interested in literary nationalism and gift exchange. Responsibilities: OCR correction, TEI encoding, project development, issue previews

Fallon is a Ph.D. student in English. She is currently studying developments in late medieval semiotics and their impact on contemporary perceptions of British outlawry. Fallon worked as one of the first graduate assistants to LSU's Digital Scholarship Lab. Responsibilities: OCR correction, TEI encoding, project development
Gilliland is a PhD student in English. Responsibilities: OCR correction, TEI encoding, project development, issue previews
Johnson is a PhD candidate in History. Responsibilities: OCR correction, TEI encoding, project development, issue previews

Kennedy is Boyd Professor of English, and has published extensively about Edgar A. Poe. He founded LSU's first digital humanities project on Edgar A. Poe, focused on the four main journals that Poe edited. The current project builds from this foundation.
Key is a Metadata Librarian for LSU Libraries.
Powell is a PhD student in English. Responsibilities: OCR correction, TEI encoding, project development, issue previews
Yantis is a graduate student in Library & Information Sciences. Responsibilities: OCR correction
Julia Flanders of Northeastern University's Digital Scholarship Group provided TEI guidance.
